I hope this message finds everyone well and having fun this summer!

I would like all our Big Stone City School families to know that our school has formed a committee and has been meeting regularly for quite some time now on the topic of how we are going to start school this fall. The plan will be to have full detailed information at our school registration day, August 4, if not sooner. There has been some talk that in mid-July there will be more substantial guidance given by the state to help in our decision making.

I would like to tell you about Kadence Rausch-Frank 8th grade student from Big Stone City School and how she received an award from the Junior Scholastic magazine.

Each year at Big Stone City School, middle school students are entered in a contest to draw and decorate a map from a country chosen by the Junior Scholastic Magazine. The students have to use clues to figure out what country the "Mapman" has visited. They then need to draw a map and decorate it with things that are meaningful to that country. This year, the country was Sri Lanka. There was one national winner and 25 runners up from all over America. Kadence was a runner up and will receive recognition in the magazine and a "Mapman" t-shirt. We are proud of the nice job she did!

I hope that everyone is staying healthy and safe!

post_text: Recess and outside expectations: We will be following the following procedure for outside PE, recess and before/after school time. If it feels like 45 or less, students are expected to have a sweatshirt, sweater or coat. If it feels like 30 or less, students are expected to have a coat, hat or gloves. If snow is on the ground, they must have snow pants and boots. If it feels like 0 or less, we will be inside. Naturally, conditions in the Fall and Spring can change quickly, so make sure your child is prepared by leaving some extra outside clothes at school. Our goal is to enjoy the time outside, but also understand that 30 degrees is chilly and can be uncomfortable.

On September 20th the students received their first ROAR goal. An adventure hike through space with Chris Roberts, a Big Stone City School Alumni and 2001 graduate of Ortonville. Chris currently works at NASA and is an engineer for a portion of the International Space Station. Our students were able to learn about Chris's education, his job at NASA, some other space facts and were also able to ask him questions.

The students enjoyed this surprise visitor with Big Stone City roots.

Thank you Chris for coming and sharing your story with us!!
